11:13 am
BE

Our cautious view on HSBC since the start of the year has been driven by our
below-consensus revenue forecasts (JPMe 4% below Bloomberg consensus
2017 revs) and our concern that a normalization of the EM NPL cycle was not
fully reflected in valuation. With the revenue environment continuing to
deteriorate, we see further downside to consensus EPS forecasts (JPMe 18%
below Bbg cons 2017) which is likely to weigh on the yield support (8.6% unadj).
We believe that an ordinary & special dividend framework may be better
suited to analyze the sustainability of HSBC’s dividend with our current
forecasts leading us to view 34c ordinary dividend as sustainable, with the
remaining 17c viewed as a special dividend subject to regulatory and cyclical
earnings uncertainty. With HSBC shares trading at 0.8x P/TNAV, we prefer
LLOY for dividend yield and STAN at 0.5x for EM recovery.

BE

 Normalizing impairment drives cyclical EPS weakness: We expect a
normalization of impairment from 39bps to 56bps by 2018E which is likely
to pressure EPS and DPS growth ahead. We highlight that the 20yr average
impairment for HSBC is 105bps (73bps ex subprime) and we do not assume
impairment moving back to the normalized rate. As sensitivity, assuming
75bp impairment in ‘17E would result in -16% EPS impact and 12.4x PE.
 Dividend sustainability analysis: HSBC’s DPS payout ratio has increased
from 45% to 79% in the last five years and rises to 112% on a stated basis
on our 2017 forecasts. Since 2010, the scrip option has also increased share
count by a cumulative 9%. We estimate that CT1 rises to 13.4% by 2018
before regulatory impact from RWA harmonization. Given the uncertainty
over the impact of Basel-driven RWA changes and a relatively small Pillar
2A buffer (1.3%) for offset, we believe there may be limited excess capital
to support an uncovered dividend. Hence, we look at the dividend within an
ordinary/special dividend framework similar to Lloyds and UBS.
 Assuming BoCom stake de-consolidation in 2017: BoCom stake carrying
value ($15.3bn) has been above FV ($9.3bn) for more than 44 months and
overstates EPS by 11% (9% net of dividends) and TNAV by 4%. We expect
accounting deconsolidation from 2017. JPM is UW BoCom.
 EPS and PT cut: We cut our HSBC adj. EPS estimates by -3% in FY16-
18E driven by lower revenue expectations and as a result we cut our Dec-16
SoTP-based PT to 400p (prev. 410p).

BE

But that's a bit of a tangent. Let's get back to the miners.

BE

In our view we are past trough levels
across some commodities, including zinc, aluminium, nickel and coking
coal. Demand is improving, with sentiment also helped by a recovering oil
price and softer US$, and we have raised our China apparent steel
demand estimates for 2016 from -6% to -2.4% due to a more constructive
view from our China team on infra spend in 2016. Investors are grappling
with the question over whether performance YTD is just seasonal or a more
sustainable recovery, but it may not be until later in Q2 when we can better
judge this (prices seasonally correct lower in May / June). Structurally we
still see iron ore and copper in surplus over the next three years.

BE

Better demand, low inventories and weaker
sequential supply have boosted iron ore prices to over $55/t in early Q2,
well above market expectations. However, we expect the market to tip back
into a surplus by late 2016 / 2017 and forecast prices to fall to $40/t in
H216. We exclude any companies with significant iron ore exposure from
our top picks. We like South 32 which offers a strong balance sheet and
cheap valuation and COAL.BO which benefits from a strong balance sheet,
high volume growth and dividend yield of over 8%.

11:19 am
BE

We have lowered our copper demand estimates globally to
~2.5% pa for the next three years (in line with the long term average) and
believe the market may still be two years away from reaching an inflection
point and we now forecast prices to fall back to $2/lb in Q4 this year. We
forecast improving fundamentals and prices in both the zinc and aluminium
markets. Our top picks (BOL.ST, HBM.TO, LUN.TO) offer a combination of
zinc exposure and conservative balance sheets. We like Alcoa (AA.N) for
its restructuring story and SOTP valuation upside.

BE

We recently upgraded our gold price
forecasts following the continuing positive fundamentals (declining real
interest rates, Fed's hike deferral, a weaker USD and increased safe haven
demand). We target good operators and FCF generation (AEM.N, ABX.N,
NEM.N, and THO.TO) and like Zijin Mining (2899.HK) for its growth
reacceleration. Alrosa (ALRS.MM) offers diamond exposure where we are
cautiously optimistic on the outlook for the diamond market and expect
Alrosa to generate strong FCFs and return peer leading dividends.

PM

Further to yesterday's announcement, Sports Direct ("the Group") would like to correct inaccurate information that was published on The Guardian website by making the following comments.

PM

"This property is a perfect strategic fit. The Group has had a long-standing interest in acquiring a flagship site in London for a 20,000 sq ft Flannels.com store along with 20,000 sq ft of prestige office space to replace New Cavendish Street, which was sold for £44m last May (2015). At that time the Group said its plan was to acquire a prime London site in order to gain more space and strengthen its market position. The Group has searched extensively before seizing this opportunity.

"The deal vindicates the Group's faith in Michael Murray, who has successfully played a pivotal role executing the property strategy. This is one of the hottest freehold sites in London, superbly located in the mid-section of Oxford Street to the east of Oxford Circus. It is just a short walk from the forthcoming new Crossrail link at Tottenham Court Road, which will bring an estimated 50,000 extra people a day to the station in 2018 and it will bring 1.5million people to within 45 minutes by train."

I think the key things are:

- The Board allowed McCormick to do extensive due diligence. It is their decision to walk away.

- The Management are now committed to completing the turnaround of the business and delivering value.

- Group has pledged to double its rate of sales growth (from 1-2% to 2-4%)

- As a next step PF will complete the Relationship Agreement with Nissin Foods, which will give them access to international markets (current only 4% of turnover)

Share price is still a third higher than where it was before all this began.

BE

11:43 am
BE

BE

In the meantime, here's Davy.

BE

McCormick withdraws proposal to acquire Premier Foods
McCormick this morning announced that it does not intend to make an offer for Premier Foods. McCormick completed its due diligence review of Premier Foods and concluded that it would not be able to propose a price that would be recommended by the Board of Premier Foods while also delivering appropriate returns for McCormick shareholders. Accordingly, McCormick has withdrawn its proposal to acquire Premier Foods.
Medium-term outlook still improved for Premier Foods
In its defence against McCormick’s approach, Premier Foods cited an improving medium- term growth outlook. Business momentum supports 1-2% sales growth guidance communicated previously. It announced new strategic initiatives to accelerate growth support, raising the medium-term sales guidance from 1-2% to 2-4% – a target that the Board believes is highly deliverable. To support the new strategic initiatives, it expects to incur initial upfront investment of £2-4m in FY2016/2017. It also highlights that further upside potential can come from cooperation with Nissin.
New strategic growth initiatives
Premier’s new strategic growth initiatives announced on April 6th are as follows: build on the successful performance of Sweet Treats over the last 18 months by investing further in Cake on the Go offering; leverage brands and retailer relationships to drive growth outside ambient and into chilled groceries; accelerate the International roll-out strategy, which is already demonstrating the potential to deliver important growth for the future.
Nissin Foods’ intentions remain unknown
In addition to establishing a cooperation agreement, Nissin Foods also acquired a 17.27% shareholding in Premier Foods from Warburg Pincus at a price of 63p per share. It subsequently increased its holding to just under 20%. Nissin will take up a seat on the Board of Premier Foods, but it is unclear if it will increase its shareholding further or stay at just under 20%.

11:44 am
BE

And Mark Brumby at Langton.

BE

Where to from here? Short term.
· Share register may churn, chancers will get out

· Standard Life & Paulson (vocal in their comments) need to commit or sell

· Meaning short term weakness is unavoidable

Where to from here? Medium term.
· The last month has been a defining point between eras

· 1mth ago (yes, just 1mth), PFD was a friendless, highly indebted & un-investable basket case

· Now it has had bid approaches, has a supportive shareholder (at 63p) & could grow at double (more including Nissin) the rate previously asserted - here

Conclusion:
· A left-field approach (which would get MKC out of the 6mth sin-bin) is possible

· And operationally, management will be under intense pressure to deliver

· Here the signs are good. Capex, marketing, exports, Paul Hollywood, TLC re Batchelors etc.

· And, if this is an investible company, it’s too cheap

· EBITDA c£147m pays interest (£42m), capex (£25m), pension (£57m) & cuts debt by greater than £20m

· PER is 5x (pre the growth mentioned above) & EV/EBITDA is

BE

Here's Morgan Stanley.

11:50 am
BE

Bottom line: We have spoken with the company. Overall, this is a decent
update from Tesco at its prelims, with Tesco's operating profit coming in ~2%
ahead of (tempered) expectations. The outlook message however is a
reasonably cautious one, mentioning a challenging environment in the UK and
investments in the proposition and we believe that consensus could have to
drift down when it comes to FY17 operating profit forecasts to around
~£1,180m vs. £1,251m currently (Vuma), a ~5% decline. With the shares
having been strong into the numbers, we would expect a pull back today.
Focus at the analyst meeting on Wednesday will probably be on the guidance,
including prospects for further positive LFL sales in the UK and colour on the
margin evolution / cash generation in the UK.

BE

Group: Overall, Tesco's operating profit reached £944m in FY16 vs. £936m for
Bloomberg consensus and ~£940m Tesco guidance (with proceeds in excess
of that meant to be reinvested in its customer proposition). UK & ROI EBIT
came in a touch above expectations, as did Tesco's International business
(helped by still strong top line trends, but also the release of the Hungarian
retail sales tax provision). Tesco Bank however was further hit by lower
interchange fees and came in below expectations. Further down the P&L, net
finance costs increased YoY to £643m, impacted by net pension costs.

PM

Sell off of Tesco is gathering pace, btw

11:51 am

Off 5.7% now

BE

Valuation: As of yesterday’s close price, and on consensus CY16 numbers,
Tesco is trading on EV/EBITDA and P/E multiples of 10.0x and 23.8x. This
compares with 7.7x and 18.4x respectively for the European food retail sector.

BE

The combination of high multiples, a cautious outlook and high market
expectations should lead to a multiple contraction, in our view. We would
be taking profits on shares that have rallied on the back of too bullish
assumptions on its pace of recovery in a UK market that remains highly
challenged, both cyclically and structurally. We see better value in
Carrefour.

11:57 am
BE

So .......

BE

The ‘blackout’ period in the UK IPO process between publication of research by syndicate banks and the circulation of the ‘pathfinder’ prospectus means that the pathfinder and approved prospectuses, both key sources of information, are made available too late in the process to be used by buy-side investors, non-syndicate banks’ analysts and independent research providers. When coupled with a lack of access to the issuer’s management for non-syndicate bank analysts, this reduces the diversity and independence of information available to investors.

BE

Yep.

11:58 am
BE

Allocations of shares in IPOs are skewed towards buy-side investors from whom banks derive greater revenues from other business lines (e.g. trading commission). Although these investors may be long-term holders and of benefit to issuing clients, there is also a risk that allocations do not align with issuing clients’ best interests and may shut out other investors.

BE

Yep.

BE

But then .............

11:58 am
BE

League tables that rank investment banks can be misleading because some banks carry out loss-making transactions purely to generate a higher position in league tables. Furthermore, banks routinely present league tables to clients in a way that inflates their own position. Many clients are aware of these practices; nonetheless we believe they impede effective client choice.

BE

League tables? That's the third concern?

PM

Well, the fact that banks are so obsessed by the league tables tells you something must be wrong

11:59 am

PM

12:01 pm

JPMorgan profit fall not as bad as feared
A “challenging” market environment has hit JPMorgan, the biggest US bank by assets, which has reported a 7 per cent fall in first-quarter profit from a year ago.

However, profits were better than gloomy analyst forecasts, coming in at $1.35 a per share, on revenue of $24.1bn. Analysts had been expecting earnings per share of $1.26, down from $1.45 a year ago.
